I am new to programming and I don’t have anyone to mentor me I know Java and I have learned wpilib to a good level but I don’t understand how the code should be build

Like how do the subclass should look like ? and how the commands should look like ?

Is there a tutorial that I can watch ? I need a good one even if it take 6 hour or so

Thanks everyone

A new programmer

Anderson","username":"flamekeeper","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/flamekeeper/{size}/267435_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-18T12:03:37.671Z","cooked":"

Hello! If you already know java and a bit of wpilib, then I’d say the next step would probably be looking at other teams repositories. Heres a bunch of FRC code bases. I’d also recommend taking a look at the LLK, they have a LOT of resources for FRC stuff, and they update quite frequently.

Subclass and command structures vary a bit from team to team, so you’ll probably develop your own habits with them. I can link you my team’s repo if you would like, but the first link sorts teams by EPA so you’ll likely find much better and more organized code there.

I can try to help more if I have time this week, good luck!

Edit: saw this thread, it is probably very relevant here: As a beginner frc programmer what concepts or things should i learn or learn to do first?

If you don’t have a preferred style yet, my suggestion is to use the “instance factory” structure.

Command-based best practices for 2025: community feedback Programming
I’m currently working on a “best practices” article around usage of the WPILib Command-based framework for frc-docs. It’s been 5 years since the “v2” framework debuted, and both the library and its usage have evolved quite a bit in that time. The documentation has changed, as well, but is starting to show some structural cracks as teams start doing things that require more flexibility than our basic examples demonstrate. I don’t have time to write a full set of new documentation, but I do hav…
FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Organizing Command-Based Robot Projects

As robot code becomes more complicated, navigating, understanding, and maintaining the code takes up more and more time and energy. Making changes to the code often becomes more difficult, sometime...

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Command Compositions

Individual commands are capable of accomplishing a large variety of robot tasks, but the simple three-state format can quickly become cumbersome when more advanced functionality requiring extended ...

What does this look like, in practice?

I find example-based learning to work better than a tutorial that gives general rules. At this time, I can give you one set of examples from my team’s 2025 code. I can also provide more examples later.

github.com/FRCTeam695/Goldfish

src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/AlgaeDislodger.java

main 
package frc.robot.subsystems;

import java.util.function.DoubleSupplier;

import com.ctre.phoenix6.BaseStatusSignal;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.configs.TalonFXSConfiguration;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.controls.DutyCycleOut;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.controls.MotionMagicVoltage;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.hardware.TalonFXS;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.signals.MotorArrangementValue;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.signals.NeutralModeValue;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.signals.StaticFeedforwardSignValue;

import edu.wpi.first.networktables.DoublePublisher;
import edu.wpi.first.networktables.NetworkTable;
import edu.wpi.first.networktables.NetworkTableInstance;
import edu.wpi.first.networktables.PubSubOption;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj2.command.Command;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj2.command.SubsystemBase;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj2.command.button.Trigger;
This file has been truncated. show original

Relevant excerpt; the code that defines the public interface of the AlgaeDislodger subsystem:

public Trigger atSetpoint;

...

atSetpoint = new Trigger(
        ()-> Math.abs(controlMM.Position - m_talon.getPosition().getValueAsDouble()) < 1);

...

public Command goToPosition(DoubleSupplier setpoint) {
    return run(() -> m_talon.setControl(controlMM.withPosition(setpoint.getAsDouble())));
}

public Command dump(){
    return goToPosition(()-> Constants.Alagizer.dump).until(atSetpoint)
                .andThen(goToPosition(()-> Constants.Alagizer.dislodgeAngle).until(atSetpoint))
                .andThen(goToPosition(()-> 0).until(atSetpoint));
}

public Command voltageControl(DoubleSupplier setpoint) {
    DutyCycleOut output = new DutyCycleOut(0);
    return run(() -> {
        output.Output = setpoint.getAsDouble();
        m_talon.setControl(output);
    });
}

The pieces are:

  • a Trigger; an object that holds a block of code that runs on a schedule and checks for a boolean
  • three Command factory methods (i.e., methods that construct and return objects); they “box up” segments of code as Commands for later use:
    – run closed-loop control; it drives the arm to a particular angle
    – compose multiple Commands and Triggers to runs the arm to three positions, in sequence
    – run the motor in duty cycle (i.e., open-loop) mode (for testing/tuning/setup)

Because they’re written inside the Subsystem, the call to run() is more than shorthand for "create a Command; it also includes that Subsystem as a requirement for the Command so you don’t have to. This is part of why you would want to do it within the Subsystem instead of outside.

(Syntax info: the () -> ... or () -> { ... } block is called a Lambda Expression. It’s a way to “box up” a chunk of code that can be run/called later. You can read a lot about this elsewhere. This is a specific example: one that takes no parameters and returns nothing.)

The other reason to do it inside the Subsystem is so that you don’t have to expose all of the details of the Subsystem with public methods or fields. These Commands are going to change when the Subsystem changes, so they should be close-coupled. However, they also shouldn’t represent everything that you can do with it, just the base stuff that needs to be close-coupled.

The two simple ones above (goToPosition() and voltageControl()) also lack end conditions; they never end. However, dump() has three end conditions, one for each position. These are achieved by calling .until(atSetpoint), which says, “once the Trigger goes true, terminate this one and move on to the next.”

Then there’s the actual usage outside of the subsystem:

One simple button binding example (in RobotContainer):

driver.povUp().onTrue(Alagizer.dump());

(“on the driver’s controller, when the D-pad’s ‘up’ becomes true (“pressed”), dump the algae”)

Composition with climber (algae mechanism is physically in the way of the climb):

// enter "climb mode"
    driver.y().whileTrue(
      parallel(
        Alagizer.goToPosition(()-> Constants.Alagizer.holdRamp),
        Climber.runClimb(1),
        Swerve.rotateToAngle(()-> (Swerve.isRedAlliance() ? -90 : 90), driver::getRequestedChassisSpeeds)
      )
    );

"on the driver’s controller, when the Y button becomes true (“pressed”), do all three things at once:

  • Using the Alagizer, flip and hold up the ramp
  • Run the climber [outward] (yes, this is a magic number, and I’m going to ask them to refactor)
  • Rotate the robot to a particular angle (i.e., face the cage) and continue driving with the stick (this is also not a good name and contains magic numbers. Sue me; it was written by teenagers.)

Example of this during the match (watch the lower-middle screen at 2:26)

Note that there’s no need to specify the Subsystem for the parallel() (i.e., run all these Commands at the same time until they all finish) because that info was packaged up in the factory methods.

Additional example from WPILib:

github.com

allwpilib/wpilibjExamples/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj/examples/hatchboti...

Official Repository of WPILibJ and WPILibC. Contribute to wpilibsuite/allwpilib development by creating an account on GitHub.

agree with what people have said above about finding good reference material and also want to add that actually writing (or rewriting) a complete robot codebase and practicing implementing everything was probably what helped me most with building that familiarity. if you still have access to your robot from in season or can build a new drivebase/offseason robot, testing it on that will also help

Hi there, I know a lot of other people have sent a lot of helpful resources already, but I hope these additional resources will also help you!

Team 3061, Huskie Robotics, releases an Open Source library each year that prevents us from rewriting the same robot code and is focused on a swerve-based drivetrain.

It’s called 3061 Lib, and our lead mentor releases videos explaining every part of 3061 lib, so I would highly reccomend watching those videos if you want some clarification!

We use 3061 Lib as our base code for each year, so understanding it might help you to build your own code for the build season. Also feel free to use 3061 Lib as your base code for the build season!

I hope this helps, and please reach out with any questions.

building on this cus I agree, if you don’t have a robot this is a great opportunity to learn how to use simulation to test your code

FRC code can take many forms, commonly you’ll see teams use java command based architecture. This is (imo) the most simple architecture there is and the easiest to learn. The way I learned was creating new projects of templates in WPILib project creator. This gives you full robot code and allows you to see what it should look like.

Spectrum has some great resources avaliable on there website for learning java and training. I wish you luck!

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-09-24T03:43:04.239Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":58,"readers_count":57,"score":11.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":506402,"topic_slug":"hi-i-am-new-to-programming-and-i-need-help","display_username":"Kegan Cherry","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.spectrum3847.org/resources/spectrum-resources","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Spectrum Resources | Spectrum3847","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73648,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/hi-i-am-new-to-programming-and-i-need-help/506402/7","custom_user_title":"Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3746719,"name":"Owen Flanagan","username":"OwenF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/edb3f5/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-09-24T04:38:56.019Z","cooked":"

I would recommend starting by stealing from other people and modifying there code. If you use library’s like YAGSL or YAMS they will have example projects you can steal. If not I would find an open source team with a similar level to yours (aka not a top level team) and steal from them instead. From there you can edit the code to fit your use. In general I find it much easier to edit an existing robot than to work from scratch and these examples will also give you a lot of examples of what a command or a sub class can look like.

Also don’t underestimate the resources out there. I have spent far to much time implementing my own jank solutions because I simply didn’t know what libraries were out there. Here is a list of software that you might find useful. Its by no means comprehensive but these are the tools I wish somebody had told me about.

Advantage scope for debugging and displaying robot data (in addition to its primary use as a log player)
YAGSL will handle swerve for you.
YAMS will handle the low level mechanisms for you (Its not out for another 2 weeks but its great trust).
Pathplanner will handle path planning and auto drive mostly for you.
Photon vision will make custom vision much easier to implement.
The WPI robot simulation tools can allow you to simulate your robot on any computer. This makes debugging so much easier in every way.
Maple sim makes that WPI robot simulation a lot easier and comes with great examples

WPILIB also does A LOT of stuff but I want to specifically highlight 2 things that I don’t see given enough love.

  1. It comes with abstract measurements like Angle and Distance. This allows you to easily handle values without worrying about the units.
  2. Their positional classes like Pose2d, and rotation3d can do a lot of geometry for you. Its worth understanding all of the options and what they can be used for because it will save you a lot of time in the long run.
